headline: Government Responds to Lance Armstrong in Whistleblower Suit
summary: The Department of Justice responded to Lance Armstrong on Monday, saying the Postal Service will forever be linked to the 'sordid scandal.'

headline: Old Fashioned Place-Kickers Retain Toehold in Ohio
summary: In Ohio, square-toe football kickers maintain a place in a sport dominated in recent decades by soccer-style kickers.

headline: Burger King Tries New French Fries
summary: Burger King is going after what it calls "lapsed users" with new french fries that promise fewer calories and less fat.

headline: A Helping Hand at Sea
summary: Ralph Gardner Jr. talks with Captain Joe Frohnhoefer and his son, Captain Joe Frohnhoefer III, of Sea Tow Eastern Long Island.

headline: Lance Armstrong Asks to Be Deposed for Multiple Suits in One Sitting
summary: Motion was in response to a whistleblower suit accusing him of defrauding his team's biggest sponsor, the United States Postal Service, by using performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Obama Endorses de Blasio for Mayor
summary: President Barack Obama's endorsement of Democrat Bill de Blasio for mayor didn't spring from a close friendship, but the two men's biographies nevertheless are marked by similarities

headline: Brooklyn Firm Creates Furniture From Bowling Alley Remnants
summary: As bowing lanes have closed, demolition crews and lumber companies have sought out CounterEvolution and others to find new uses for the bowling-alley wood.

headline: Killer of Fashion-Designer Girlfriend Is Sentenced
summary: Nicholas Brooks told a Manhattan courtroom Monday that he loved and missed the woman he was convicted of murdering, but his declaration failed to sway the judge, who sentenced him to the maximum 25 years to life.

headline: Ex-Traders Citing 'Whale' in Defense
summary: Two former traders at J.P. Morgan Chase accused of overstating the value of their group's positions are pointing the finger at Bruno Iksil, the so-called London whale.

headline: TD Bank Fined $52.5 Million
summary: U.S. regulators penalized Toronto-Dominion Bank over its alleged role in imprisoned attorney Scott Rothstein's $1.2 billion Ponzi scheme.

headline: Insurers Fight for the Healthy
summary: Health insurers are making a big push to hang onto their policyholders ahead of new government-run exchanges expected to roll out next week, but state regulators have accused some of misleading those customers in the process.

headline: U.S. Readies Civil Suit Against J.P. Morgan on Mortgages
summary: Justice Department officials are preparing to file a civil lawsuit against J.P. Morgan Chase over the bank's handling of residential mortgage-backed securities before the financial crisis.

headline: Insights in the Interchange on Stage
summary: In this week's Curtain Raisers, actor Michael Zegen opted to see Ethan Coen's "Women or Nothing," directed by David Cromer at the Linda Gross Theater.

headline: Manning Is Usually Much Harder to Sack
summary: The Giants' Eli Manning isn't usually handled like he was by the Panthers on Sunday.

headline: Jets Do Push-Ups for Penalties
summary: Rex Ryan says 20 penalties in a game is unacceptable...so drop and give him 10.

headline: BofA Ordered to Pay About $2.2 Million for Alleged Hiring Bias
summary: Bank of America was ordered to pay a total of about $2.2 million in back wages and interest to 1,147 African-American job applicants for alleged race-based hiring discrimination at the bank's Charlotte, N.C., location in the 1990s and early 2000s.

headline: Harvey Isn't Throwing
summary: The clock is ticking for Matt Harvey, but he hasn't made much progress.

headline: LightSquared Lenders Object to Board Pick
summary: Lenders to hedge-fund manager Falcone's LightSquared on Monday questioned the selection of an independent LightSquared director to help oversee a sale of the wireless telecommunications firm.

headline: Kenyan President Takes On New Role—As Uniter
summary: President Uhuru Kenyatta was a lightning rod for Kenya's ethnic divisions before Saturday's attack on a popular Nairobi shopping mall. Now, he is trying to stitch his wounded country together.

headline: Former FBI Agent to Plead Guilty in Leak
summary: Federal authorities said a longtime FBI bomb expert agreed to plead guilty Monday to disclosing classified information to the Associated Press about a 2012 bomb investigation.

headline: Josef Joffe: Merkel's Gilded Status Quo
summary: The hallmark of the new German consensus is an all-providing state that taxes, spends and regulates.

headline: Peter Funt: The Holiday Calendar Hits Hyperspeed
summary: Everything is moving up. 'Breaking Bad' ends in September? That's when TV series used to.

headline: U.S., Iran Icebreaker Set at U.N.
summary: Iran's foreign minister and Kerry plan to meet at the U.N. General Assembly, in the highest-level meeting between the U.S. and Tehran in 30 years.

headline: Florida Curbs Role in Education Consortium
summary: Florida is dialing back its participation in a national group developing exams for tougher math and reading standards known as the Common Core, dealing another setback to an effort that has come under increasing fire.

headline: Bret Stephens: Striking Deals With Despots
summary: Stalin played FDR in 1945. Iran's Rouhani now attempts to do the same with President Obama.

headline: Microsoft Upgrades Surface Tablets
summary: Microsoft unveiled the second generation of its homemade Surface tablets, tweaking the devices with faster speeds and better battery life.

headline: Bennett and Beach: The Hypocrisy Of Congress's Gold-Plated Health Care
summary: Special subsidies for Hill workers trample on the Founders' code of equal application of the law.

headline: Citigroup Cuts Mortgage Staffing
summary: The end of the refinancing boom continues to shake up the U.S. banking sector, as Citigroup Inc. said Monday it laid off 1,000 workers in its mortgage business.

headline: French-Inspired Charm in Vietnam
summary: A three-story colonial-style villa offers well-crafted interiors and a sweeping view of lush piney mountains on a tranquil slope in Da Lat, Vietnam.

headline: Athletes to Elderly: The Science of Trips and Falls
summary: Scientists are finding that maintaining stability and balance with each step we take requires complex coordination. The research could someday help athletes and prevent falls among the elderly.

headline: GM Debt Sheds a 'Junk' Label
summary: General Motors agreed to repurchase about $3.2 billion of preferred stock from a UAW trust, and Moody's bestowed an investment-grade debt rating on the company.

headline: Thesis Twist: Dancing Your Ph.D.
summary: Scientists from Australia to the Netherlands are making interpretive dance videos based on their Ph.D. dissertations. To make an esoteric thesis come alive, they leap, swoon, spin and krump.

headline: Taper Delay Lifts U.K. Equities
summary: Some investors are betting the momentum that has carried U.S. stocks to record highs is shifting across the Atlantic.

headline: West Bank Clashes Erupt
summary: New clashes and threats erupted in Hebron, a West Bank city that has been a tinderbox for Arab-Jewish tensions, days ahead of meetings in the U.S. to assess progress in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.

headline: Agrium Adds to Warnings on Potash
summary: Canada's Agrium warned that weak demand for potash is hurting its profit, in a further indication of how the break-up of a cartel is hurting the mining companies who dominate sales of the fertilizer ingredient.

headline: Pioneer of Environmental Movement Had Ear of Presidents
summary: Ruth Patrick created methods of monitoring water pollution used around the world, and as a pioneer of the emerging environmental movement, she worked with government and industry to clean up rivers and streams. She died Monday at age 105.

headline: Chrysler Files for IPO
summary: Read the filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Holiday Hiring Uneven, so Far
summary: Wal-Mart said it plans to hire 55,000 seasonal employees for the holidays and will transition tens of thousands part-timers to full-time. Kohl's plans to boost seasonal jobs, but Target will give current workers more hours.

headline: Choppy Seas, Clear Horizon for Carnival
summary: Even after a spate of accidents, Carnival's investment thesis still looks compelling.

headline: Vietnam Stocks Emerge From Slump
summary: Vietnam's main stock-market index is up 16% this year, one of the best performers among emerging markets.

headline: A History of Chrysler
summary: Take a look back at the car company's history, including its recent IPO.

headline: England Taps Three Rookies
summary: Heard on the Pitch: Ballance, Rankin and Stokes named to England's Ashes traveling squad; AC Milan's Balotelli gets three-match ban.

headline: Photos of the Day: Sept. 23
summary: In today's pictures, a zebra at a zoo in France, an elderly protester with a cane in Athens, soldiers at a mall in Kenya, and more.

headline: U.K. Cautiously Welcomes Talks with Iran
summary: U.K. Foreign Secretary William Hague offered a cautious response to the promise of talks between leading powers and top Iranian officials in coming days, saying the new government in Tehran must match positive statements with actions.

headline: Otis, Carrier to Be Combined
summary: United Technologies is folding Otis elevators in with its Carrier air-conditioning business. The group will seek more work in emerging markets.

summary: The dollar retreated after a Federal Reserve official said the U.S. economy has not rebounded enough to warrant a rollback of the central bank's easy money policies.

summary: The New York Fed said it would be undergoing tests of a new tool the central bank may use when the time comes to tighten monetary policy.

headline: Casillas in a League of His Own
summary: Spain's national goalkeeper can barely get a game at Real Madrid.

headline: Air France-KLM Weighs Fate of Alitalia Stake
summary: Air France-KLM's board discussed whether to increase the airline's stake in struggling Alitalia or to bail out but said it wanted more information from the Italian carrier.

headline: City of Light Tells Sephora: 'Lights Out by 9'
summary: A Champs Élysées cosmetics store that attracts six million people a year has become the new front line in France's battle over working hours.

headline: Voices: On Preparing Business Owners for a Staff Loss
summary: 'When business owners don't have to worry about losing key employees, they can focus more on growth.'

headline: Fed Officials' Comments Boost Treasurys
summary: Treasurys advanced as several Federal Reserve officials voiced support for continuing accommodative policy actions.

headline: Prisons for the Poor
summary: Chicago's housing projects could seem like war zones, garbage dumps, brothels or drug dens. They were also people's homes. Walter Vatter reviews "High Rise Stories," edited by Audrey Petty.

summary: Companies are pushing back against a proposed overhaul of accounting rules for leases that could add hundreds of billions of dollars in debt to the companies' balance sheets.

summary: In rare downgrades of Chinese bonds, Dagong Global Credit Rating warns about construction companies.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Damian Thompson advises going easy on the phrase 'religion of peace.'

headline: Spain's Uphill Climb From Recession
summary: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy said in an interview the country faces more austerity before it can regain its footing after emerging from a two-year contraction.

headline: Correction
summary: At its peak, the Kennecott Mines in Alaska separated as much as 1,200 tons of ore from waste rock every day.

headline: The Case for Natural Gas as a Fuel Is a Very Strong One
summary: The Obama administration has fostered the belief that natural gas is a "dead end" fuel by seriously overestimating emissions of methane (the principal component of natural gas) from production operations.

headline: The GOP Must Not Waver in Using Its House Majority
summary: The "Power of 218" (Review & Outlook, Sept. 16) compares conservatives fighting to defund ObamaCare to kamikazes, while conveniently ignoring the history of past legislative showdowns with President Obama.

headline: Seib: How to Understand House GOP
summary: To understand House Republicans, first it's necessary to recognize who is in the House Republican conference. Second, it's necessary to remember how they got to Washington in the first place, writes Gerald F. Seib.

headline: Obama Vows Aid to Kenya, Assails Terror Group
summary: President Barack Obama, calling al-Shabaab "one of the most vicious terrorist organizations in the world," said he spoke with Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta about the tragedy in Nairobi and promised U.S. assistance with the subsequent investigation.

headline: In Tough Quarter for Banks, Fortune Favors the Bold
summary: The key driver of big banks' profitability—trading in bonds, currencies and commodities—has been whipsawed by perceptions of Fed policy in the third quarter. Banks' risk appetite will be crucial to their results.

headline: Students Press on Bangladesh Factories
summary: VF, Nike and other companies that produce logo gear for colleges are being pressed by student groups to sign on to a binding Bangladesh safety accord.

headline: Kenya Westgate Mall Siege Hour by Hour
summary: The terrorist siege of an upscale Nairobi shopping mall pushed into a third day Monday. Review some of the weekend's events. Times are approximate. Sources: staff reports, Associated Press

headline: Proposed Law Change Targets Drug 'Molly'
summary: Sen. Charles Schumer is pushing a bill to combat the increasing popularity of synthetic drugs after a hybrid of ecstasy known as "molly" caused the deaths of two people during a concert on Randall's Island this summer.

headline: Giant Maersk Ship Heralds New Dawn
summary: Majestic Maersk, one of the world's largest container ships, docked at its home port of Copenhagen as part of its maiden voyage, marking what the industry hopes will be a new dawn in shipping.

headline: European Stocks Slip
summary: European stocks fell as concerns about the withdrawal of U.S. monetary stimulus and the looming debt-ceiling deadline undermined sentiment.

headline: Treasury Wine Slides Amid Upheaval
summary: Treasury Wine ousted CEO David Dearie at the weekend, and the Australian winemaker's shares fell 6.3% on Monday.

headline: Talisman Might Pare Kurdistan Assets
summary: Talisman Energy is in talks to sell a stake in its operations in a potential oil-producing region of Kurdistan in northern Iraq. It hasn't had luck selling other assets earmarked for sale.

headline: Tales of the South Pacific in Beverly Hills
summary: Mitzi Gaynor, best known for her star-making performance in 'South Pacific,' is selling her Spanish-revival style home.

headline: U.N.: Use of Child Labor Is Declining
summary: The use of child workers appears to be waning as crackdowns on underage labor start to bite, a United Nations report says.

headline: Jill Tucker: Cambodia's Dangerous Transparency Problem
summary: Public disclosure in Cambodian factories can help ensure workers aren't putting their lives at risk.

headline: The Making of a Pulp Master
summary: The Travis McGee series made John D. MacDonald famous, but the books he churned out earlier were darker—and better. Lee Sandlin on these forgotten classics.
